title: Tinnitus Treatment Following Acoustic Neuroma and Meniere’s Disease
chief_complaint: I experienced a dramatic increase in the ringing in my left ear about two weeks ago. It sounds like a siren and a whooshing noise, and it is distressing and debilitating.

problem_summary.onset: Chronic tinnitus following acoustic neuroma removal 1.6 years ago; recent exacerbation lasting 2 weeks.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating tinnitus loudness; recent spike associated with new diagnosis of Cochlear Meniere's.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral tinnitus; Right unilateral deafness; Left hearing loss.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Aural fullness, roaring tinnitus, hearing loss (no vertigo).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Avoidance of noisy situations (church, restaurants), anxiety about total deafness, sleep disturbance.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Reduce fear of deafness, decrease avoidance behaviors, and manage anxiety regarding work interference.

encounters.setting: Augustana College Center for Speech, Language, and Hearing

history.present_illness: Patient had right acoustic neuroma removed 1.6 years ago resulting in profound deafness. Recently experienced 2-week spike in left ear tinnitus (siren/whooshing). Diagnosed with Cochlear Meniere's disease (hydrops) by otologist due to fluctuating tinnitus and low-frequency HL without vertigo.
history.otologic_history: Right acoustic neuroma removal. No history of ear infections. No vertigo or dizziness.
history.medical_psych_history: High blood pressure, seasonal allergies. Family history of age-related hearing loss.
history.prior_management: Fit with Bi-CROS hearing aid by local audiologist (helpful for communication).
history.patient_goals: Manage tinnitus distress, improve sleep, reduce anxiety about becoming deaf.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows profound sensorineural hearing loss (post-tumor removal). Left ear shows moderate low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss rising to mild/normal in the mid-frequencies, then sloping slightly at high frequencies.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales (Questionnaires)
tests.key_findings: Results indicate tinnitus is bothersome and substantially influences thoughts, emotions, and sleep. Spatial hearing is poor (expected with SSD).

tests.name: Client Oriented Scale of Improvement in Tinnitus (COSIT)
tests.key_findings: Three specific therapy goals identified regarding fears of deafness, avoidance of noisy situations, and anxiety about work interference.

numeric_results.Goal_1: Fears that she would become deaf and her tinnitus would get worse
numeric_results.Goal_2: Avoidance of noisy situations such as church and restaurants with family
numeric_results.Goal_3: Anxiety about tinnitus interfering with daily activities such as work

encounters.setting: Augustana College Center for Speech, Language, and Hearing

history.interval_history: Patient completed 2 months of counseling using Tinnitus Activities Treatment (group and individual). Implemented masking sounds via Bi-CROS (12 h/d) and low-level sound therapy for sleep. Kept diary of thoughts/emotions.

tests.name: Tinnitus Primary Functions Questionnaire (TPFQ)
tests.key_findings: Significant improvement in reactions to tinnitus, especially for thoughts and emotions and sleep subscales.

tests.name: Client Oriented Scale of Improvement in Tinnitus (COSIT)
tests.key_findings: Reported reduced hearing difficulties, slightly better avoidance of social situations, and much improved enjoyment of daily life.

numeric_results.Goal_2_Outcome: Avoidance of social situations slightly better (still prefers to avoid noisy places)
numeric_results.Goal_3_Outcome: Enjoys work and social activities with less fear and anxiety

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with single-sided deafness (SSD) in the right ear following acoustic neuroma removal and a moderate, low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear consistent with Cochlear Meniere's disease. Self-report measures reveal significant tinnitus handicap, particularly affecting emotional well-being and sleep, alongside expected deficits in sound localization due to SSD.
counseling_points: Explain the relationship between Cochlear Meniere's disease (hydrops) and the fluctuating low-frequency hearing loss/tinnitus.
Discuss Tinnitus Activities Treatment (TAT) to explore how thoughts dictate emotions and modify negative thought patterns.
Encourage continued use of the Bi-CROS hearing aid for communication and masking (up to 12 hours/day).
Recommend low-level sound therapy (nature sounds, music, fan) to manage tinnitus perception, especially for sleep.
Address fears of total deafness and validate the anxiety regarding work and social withdrawal.
notes_for_actor: You are very anxious about losing the hearing in your 'good' (left) ear because you are already deaf in the right.
You describe the tinnitus as a 'siren' and 'whooshing'—it is very intrusive.
You have started avoiding restaurants and church because you are afraid of the noise and can't hear well there.
You are motivated to work but worried the noise in your head will make it impossible.
